_exec_summary.SummaryText:
1.     EXECUTIVE SUMMARY 68.155
S. D. Warren Company operates an integrated pulp and paper mill.  The mill is located at 2400 Lakeshore Drive, Muskegon, Michigan.  The Pulp Mill and Utility Department operates two process units, which contain EPA listed highly hazardous chemicals over the regulated threshold.  Chlorine is used in the Utility Water Treatment Plant.  Chlorine dioxide is generated in a separate, state of the art, production unit that supplies the Bleach Plant with 1.2% solution.
S.D. Warren continuously strives to improve its accident prevention, environmental protection and emergency response programs.  Since 1980 we have developed many programs that eliminate or minimize the effects of an accidental release.  In 1992 the mill adopted the OSHA Process Management Program (PSM).  In 1999 the mill implemented the EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP program).  In 2001 the mill installed and commissioned a new R-8 state of the art chlorine dioxide generation unit.  This permitted shutting down and decommissioning of two RMP covered processes.  The first was the chlorine dioxide unit in use since 1990 including two 15,000 gallon storage tanks for 1.0% solution.  The second unit decommissioned was a bulk chlorine railcar storage, unloading, distribution and evaporation chlorination unit.  Both units had supplied the Pulp Mill Bleach Plant.  The chlorine unit had also been the primary supply to the water treatment plant.  Removal of these two units reduced the worst case area and greatly reduced the potential impact. This has significantly improved the safety of the mills operations.  All of this was accomplished in compliance with the RMP regulation.
S. D. Warren 's Risk Management Program complies with the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency's ("EPA's") Chemical Accident Prevention rule found in 40 C.F.R. Part 68.  One requirement of this rule is to submit a Risk Management Plan (RMP Plan) to the EPA whenever a unit is decommissioned.  This RMP Plan submission

satisfies the requirement.  The Plan provides the public with information about each covered process, our accident prevention programs and our emergency response planning efforts at the Muskegon mill.  S. D. Warren's complies with EPA's RMP Program.
1.1.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION AND EMERGENCY RESPONSE POLICIES (A)
S. D. Warren's accidental release prevention policy involves a unified approach. It integrates technologies, procedures and management practices.  Our prevention program complies with all applicable procedures of the U.S. EPA's Risk Management Program (RMP) found in the 40 CFR-68, Prevention Program.
1.1.1.    MANAGEMENT SYSTEM (A)(1)
S. D. Warren has a management system in place which oversees the implementation and ongoing use of the RMP elements.  The Vice President / Mill Manager is responsible for RMP implementation.  Attached is an organization chart that depicts the positions and lines of authority of this management system.  This program, along with other mill policies, eliminates and /or reduces the likelihood and consequences of a hazardous chemical release.
1.1.2.    PREVENTION PROGRAM LEVEL 3  (A)(2)
S. D. Warren maintains policies, procedures and systems as part of their prevention program.  The program is based on the EPA's Program Level 3 elements.  The RMP elements have been combined with like elements of the mill's OSHA PSM program. 
1.2.    S. D. WARREN STATIONARY SOURCE AND REGULATED SUBSTANCE HANDLING AT THE MUSKEGON, MICHIGAN SITE (b)
The mill employs 684 full-time employees (including all medical or other laid off employees), some of whom operate the covered processes.  Today, bulk chlorine in one ton containers is only used as part of the water production operations.  Chlorine dioxide is generated in the March, 2001, commissioned, single R-8 unit.  It feeds a 1.2% chlorine dioxide in water solution to the Pulp Mill Bleach Plant.
1.2.1.    SITE DESCRIPTION (b)(1)
The facility has chlorine storage at one location.  Chlorine from this system

is used in both of the mills' water treatment plants. 
The water treatment plant's only source of chlorine is from one-ton containers.  Two containers are connected to the water treatment evaporation system located in a raw water filter #57 building.  Up to eight full containers are stored in a sheltered process area adjacent to the raw water filter building #57.  The maximum inventory is 20,000 lbs. included in process and storage containers.
The boundaries of the chlorine system subject to the RMP regulation include:  the eight each one-ton container in the storage area and the raw water filter building #57, which contains two one ton containers and all associated piping, vents and exhaust systems.  It also includes the service water pump building #56, feed and injection systems.
The facility has one chlorine dioxide generation, storage and distribution process.  The R-8 process was installed in March of 2001.  Chlorine dioxide comprises approximately 1.2 % of a liquid mixture that is generated and stored in two 60,190 gallon tanks.   These tanks are surrounded by a dike system.  The maximum intended inventory of these storage tanks and associated piping, reaction vessels, etc. is equal to 13,255 lbs of chlorine dioxide.  A single vessel contains a maximum of 6,025 lbs of chlorine dioxide in the solution.  The solution is pumped to the Pulp Mill Bleach Plant for use there.
1.2.2.    REGULATED SUBSTANCE (b)(2)
Chlorine and chlorine dioxide are the only regulated substances on site which exceeds the EPA 40 CFR-68 rule threshold quantities. 
1.3.    WORST AND ALTERNATIVE CASE RELEASE SCENARIOS (c)
The worst case and alternate scenarios were evaluated using both EPA guidance and air dispersion modeling.  
An off-site consequence analysis is required by the RMP rule to estimate potential impacts to the community.  As required by RMP, S. D. Warren's off-site consequence analysis included evaluation of a worst case accidental release for both toxic chemicals and an alternative

release for each covered chemical.

1.3.1.    WORST CASE   (c)(1)
The worst case scenario involves the total release of the contents of one 60,190 gallon chlorine storage tank.  The worst case release is defined by EPA as "a release of the largest quantity of a regulated substance from a single vessel or process line failure that results in the greatest distance to an endpoint defined in ? 68.22."  40 C.F.R. ? 68.3.   EPA requires the worst-case accidental release to be modeled using highly conservative meteorological data designed to result in the maximum possible adverse impact.  Specifically, the EPA requires worst case models to be based on the hottest day of the year, occurring at night with a very slow, steady wind, which would not disperse a release effectively. Further, the modeling requirements assume that the entire contents of the largest vessel are released instantaneously.  The chances of such an event occurring on a 98?F night when the wind is blowing at 3.4 miles per hour is extremely remote.  
Worst case releases for the chlorine water treatment process were evaluated.  The evaluation was performed using B/AB and EPA's INPUFF Models.  (INPUFF was used as a chlorine dioxide release is not a dense gas.  That worst case had a significantly smaller distance to the endpoint than the release of 60,190 gallons of solution equivalent to 6,025 lbs. of chlorine dioxide.  Under the EPA mandated scenario described above, the worst-case release at the mill (for purposes of RMP) would result in a vapor cloud that could extend beyond the mill's property line.
1.3.2.    ALTERNATIVE CASE   (c)(2)
S. D. Warren developed alternative scenarios for chlorine and chlorine dioxide, which focus on more realistic releases occurring during more common meteorological conditions.  However, EPA requires modeling a release, which could impact off-site locations. After considering all criteria in the RMP rule, the process hazard analyses ("PHAs") performed on covered processes, and all

past releases from covered processes, S. D. Warren chose the following alternative release scenarios:  
1.3.2.1.    .The failure of a chlorine one ton container valve whip; and 
1.3.2.2.      The leak of a chlorine dioxide transfer pipe from the R-8 unit storage tank that feeds the bleach plant.  The leak was estimated at 10% of the total liquid solution flow or 12,500 gallons of liquid per hour.

Each of these release scenarios could result in a vapor cloud that could extend beyond the mill's property line. 
1.4.    ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM (d)
S. D. Warren's accidental release prevention program is based on OSHA's PSM program and EPA's RMP Level 3 prevention program.  The PSM program has been in place and effectively used for several years.  It is part of the standard operating procedure for the facility.  There are two parts to the program.  The first is the general overall site program.  The second is the chlorine-and chlorine dioxide specific actions within the site program.  These programs are coordinated with Muskegon fire department.
1.4.1.    GENERAL ACCIDENTAL RELEASE PREVENTION PROGRAM   (d)(1)
Facility-wide, elements of the prevention program are used for all operations.  The basic elements are described below: 
1.4.1.1.    Employee Participation.  S. D. Warren has developed and implemented a written plan of action regarding employee participation in the safety and accident prevention process.  The plan describes how employees are:  
(A)     Consulted with and obtained input they would have in the development of Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) and other PSM and RMP safety elements.
(B)     Given employees and their representative's access to all PSM and RMP information.   
1.4.1.2.    Process Safety Information:  In accordance with applicable requirements, S. D. Warren has compiled and maintains process safety information about the design, installation, maintenance, and operations of its covered processes.  This ensures that information remains current.  Employees wo

.4.1.5.    Contractors.  As part of S. D. Warren's contractor selection process we obtain and evaluate information regarding contract employer's safety performance and programs per 29 C.F.R. ? 1910.119(h).  S. D. Warren also: 
A. Informs contract employers of the known potential fire, explosion, or toxic release hazards related to the contractor's work and the covered processes;
B. Explains to contract employers the applicable provisions of the facility's integrated contingency plan (discussed below); and
C. Controls the entrance, presence and exit of contract employers and contract employees in covered process areas.
1.4.1.6.    Pre-startup Safety Review:  As required, following installation of new and/ or modifications to a covered process, a pre-startup review is conducted.  This review ensures that the process is constructed and the equipment is designed in accordance with specifications; and that appropriate safety, operating, maintenance, and emergency procedures are in place to adequately protect the health and safety of employees and the public.
1.4.1.7.    Hot Work Permit:  As part of its overall fire protection program, S. D. Warren implements a hot work permit program.  It covers all hot work operations (e.g., welding, soldering, etc.) conducted throughout the mill and on or near RMP covered processes.
1.4.1.8.    Management of Change:  S. D. Warren has established and implements a procedure to authorize and document changes in covered processes.  This procedure ensures all required considerations are addressed prior to any change to equipment, facilities, raw materials, and procedures being implemented.  This procedure also includes emergency change protocols.
1.4.1.9.    Incident Investigation.  S. D. Warren investigates each incident, which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in, a significant release of a highly hazardous chemical in the workplace.  An incident investigation team is established and consists of:

system is designed to meet the equipment design criteria of the Chlorine Institute.  The Chlorine Dioxide R-8 unit's design is as prescribed by the unit manufacturer Sterling Chemicals.  It meets or exceeds industry standards. 
1.5.    FIVE-YEAR ACCIDENT HISTORY (e)
S. D. Warren has had two minor chlorine dioxide releases in the past five years.  One was due to equipment failure and was a very small (less than 1 lb.) chemical release.  The other was equally small and was caused by human error.  There have been no loss time cases or off-site impacts to either the population or environment in the past five years. 
1.6.    EMERGENCY RESPONSE PROGRAM (f)
Emergency response procedures are contained in S. D. Warren's Emergency Response Plan (ERP).
The ERP is coordinated with and reviewed by the Muskegon Fire Department, which coordinates with the Local Emergency Planning Committee (LEPC) and HazMat Team #3, Muskegon, Michigan.
1.6.1.    PERSONNEL (f)(1)
S. D. Warren has a dedicated Plant Protection Department that is responsible for all the above mill wide safety programs.  Plus, mill employees make up the operator, maintenance and emergency response teams. 
1.7.    CHANGES TO IMPROVE SAFETY (g)
S. D. Warren discontinued the use of two processes that contain regulated substances.   The first process was shut down, isolated and decomissioned in July, 2001, was the chlorine railcar and evaporation system.   This reduced the maximum quantity in a single vessel from 180,000 pounds to 2,000 pounds.  Based on preliminary off site impact studies, the radius to the endpoint from 14 to 2 miles which reduced the area by a factor of 50. and the number of homes and facilities impacted has been drastically reduced.  The second process, also decommissioned in July, 2001, was the original chlorine dioxide generation facility.  This reduced the total chemical inventory of chlorine dioxide by 2,500 pounds.  
Changes to improve safety (recommended actions) were also identified during the recent R-8 sa

fety tour audit analysis.  The recommended actions have been evaluated and have been implemented as required 
S. D. Warren continually reviews implemented and potential safety improvements for all of its operations.  Currently, the S. D. Warren management team and process safety team are reviewing potential upgrades to the existing design of the water treatment chlorine operations to make the system even safer.  This will prevent and minimize consequences in the event of a release.
